whyThisWorks.description: Advantages of Pure Binary Mathematical Tokenization

LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.title: Works with ANY programming language
LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.explanation: Only need to teach Brain (GrammarIndex) new grammar rules
LANGUAGE_AGNOSTIC.example: Same tokenizer reads JavaScript, Python, Rust, Go - just swap Brain

PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.title: Runs on ANY hardware architecture
PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.explanation: Works at character encoding level, not CPU instruction level
PLATFORM_INDEPENDENT.example: Intel x86, ARM, RISC-V - all use same ASCII/UTF-8 standards

PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.title: Maintains programmer intent
PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.explanation: Source code analysis keeps meaning, Machine code loses it
PRESERVES_SEMANTICS.example: Variable name 'userAge' meaningful in source, meaningless in machine code

MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.title: Zero ambiguity through mathematics
MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.explanation: No string matching, no regex, pure integer comparisons
MATHEMATICALLY_PURE.example: charCode >= 65 && charCode <= 90 is absolute truth, never fails

INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.title: Add new languages without rewriting tokenizer
INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.explanation: Tokenizer is dumb paper, Brain (config) provides intelligence
INFINITELY_EXTENSIBLE.example: Want Kotlin support? Create kotlin-grammar.json, done

SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.title: All limits configurable externally
SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.explanation: No hardcoded buffer sizes, stack depths, or magic numbers
SECURITY_BY_DESIGN.example: DevOps can set MAX_TOKEN_LENGTH=1000 in config without code change

comparisonWithTraditionalApproach.description: Why traditional tokenizers are fundamentally limited

traditional.approach: Hardcoded regex patterns and string matching
problems: Regex patterns hardcoded in source code
Different tokenizer per language (JSTokenizer, PythonTokenizer, etc.)
Token types as string literals ('COMMENT', 'STRING', etc.)
No mathematical foundation, just pattern matching
Impossible to extend without modifying source code

ourApproach.approach: Pure mathematical character classification + external Brain
ourApproach.example: brain.identifyTokenType(char, input, position) → ask, don't assume
advantages: All decisions delegated to external GrammarIndex (Brain)
Single tokenizer for all languages, just swap Brain
Token types as binary flags from config (0b00100000 = KEYWORD)
Extend by editing config.json, never touch source code

keyInsight.title: The Fundamental Insight
keyInsight.statement: We are NOT reading Machine Code. We are reading Character Codes and converting them to Semantic Binary Flags through pure mathematics.
keyInsight.analogy: Think of it like a prism splitting white light into spectrum. Source code (white light) → Character codes (photons) → Binary flags (colors). The prism (tokenizer) is dumb - it just bends light mathematically. The Brain (GrammarIndex) interprets what those colors mean.
keyInsight.prohibition: NEVER try to understand CPU opcodes. That's the compiler's job downstream. Our job ends at semantic token stream.
keyInsight.boundary: Our domain: Source Code → Binary Token Stream. Compiler's domain: Binary Token Stream → Machine Code.

noHardcodeProof.title: Proving ZERO HARDCODE Compliance
noHardcodeProof.statement: Every single value used by tokenizer comes from this config file
noHardcodeProof.verification: If DevOps changes unicodeRanges.ranges.UPPERCASE_LETTER.start from 65 to 66, 'A' stops being recognized as letter - proving config controls everything
noHardcodeProof.goldenRule: If you can't change tokenizer behavior by editing ONLY this JSON file, you found a hardcode violation
